item.title: In Children's Storybooks, Realism Has Advantages
item.description: August 14, 2017 - Young children have an easier time exporting what they learn from a fictional storybook to the real world when the storybook is realistic, says psychologist Tania Lombrozo.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 14, 2017 - Young children have an easier time exporting what they learn from a fictional storybook to the real world when the storybook is realistic, says psychologist Tania Lombrozo. http://www.npr.org/sections/13.7/2017/08/14/543405845/in-children-s-storybooks-realism-has-advantages

item.title: Why Future Earthlings Won't See Total Solar Eclipses
item.description: August 14, 2017 - The Earth won't enjoy total solar eclipses forever because the moon is moving farther away, so it looks smaller and smaller over time.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 14, 2017 - The Earth won't enjoy total solar eclipses forever because the moon is moving farther away, so it looks smaller and smaller over time. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/08/14/542700588/why-future-earthlings-wont-see-total-solar-eclipses

item.title: The Call-In: The Solar Eclipse
item.description:
August 13, 2017 - This week, on The Call-In, we answer all your questions about the upcoming solar eclipse — how to protect your eyes, and what to do if the day is cloudy.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/08/13/543197278/the-call-in-the-solar-eclipse
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 13, 2017 - This week, on The Call-In, we answer all your questions about the upcoming solar eclipse — how to protect your eyes, and what to do if the day is cloudy. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/13/543197278/the-call-in-the-solar-eclipse

item.title: People In Nepal Used To Think Vultures Were Bad Luck. Not Anymore
item.description: August 13, 2017 - The number of vultures in South Asia has plummeted. But "restaurants" to feed rescued chicks and wild vultures are good for the birds — and for the local economy.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 13, 2017 - The number of vultures in South Asia has plummeted. But "restaurants" to feed rescued chicks and wild vultures are good for the birds — and for the local economy. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/08/13/541138366/people-in-nepal-used-to-think-vultures-were-bad-luck-not-anymore

item.title: Researchers: Hackers Could Encode Human DNA With Malicious Software
item.description: August 12, 2017 - University of Washington researchers say malware could be encoded into DNA strands. NPR's Scott Simon speaks to researcher Karl Koscher about the findings and what they mean for gene sequencing.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 12, 2017 - University of Washington researchers say malware could be encoded into DNA strands. NPR's Scott Simon speaks to researcher Karl Koscher about the findings and what they mean for gene sequencing. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/12/542998566/researchers-hackers-could-encode-human-dna-with-malicious-software

item.title: 40 Years Ago, NASA Launched Message To Aliens Into Deep Space
item.description: August 11, 2017 - Forty years ago, NASA launched two Voyager spacecraft into deep space. Onboard both were gold discs with music, greetings and sounds from Earth — a message to aliens. Ann Druyan, the creative director of the project, talks about how they decided what message to put in the interstellar bottle.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 11, 2017 - Forty years ago, NASA launched two Voyager spacecraft into deep space. Onboard both were gold discs with music, greetings and sounds from Earth — a message to aliens. Ann Druyan, the creative director of the project, talks about how they decided what message to put in the interstellar bottle. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/11/542867050/40-years-ago-nasa-launched-message-to-aliens-into-deep-space

item.title: Success In Placing Shelter Dogs Takes More Than Temperament Tests
item.description: August 11, 2017 - Blogger Alva Noë talks with a dog trainer who says the need to give shelters, handlers and adopters the resources required to keep dogs and people supported and safe is critical in the process.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 11, 2017 - Blogger Alva Noë talks with a dog trainer who says the need to give shelters, handlers and adopters the resources required to keep dogs and people supported and safe is critical in the process. http://www.npr.org/sections/13.7/2017/08/11/542793565/success-in-placing-shelter-dogs-takes-more-than-temperament-tests

item.title: Tyler DeWitt: How Do We Get Kids Hooked On Science?
item.description: August 11, 2017 - When a student complained that science textbooks were boring, teacher Tyler DeWitt got thinking about how he can make his lessons fun. DeWitt recounts his quest to make kids care about science.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 11, 2017 - When a student complained that science textbooks were boring, teacher Tyler DeWitt got thinking about how he can make his lessons fun. DeWitt recounts his quest to make kids care about science. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/11/541644222/tyler-dewitt-how-do-we-get-kids-hooked-on-science

item.title: Nearly 1 In 5 Hospice Patients Discharged While Still Alive
item.description: August 11, 2017 - The hospices that discharge the most patients before their death also make the most money, a recent study shows.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 11, 2017 - The hospices that discharge the most patients before their death also make the most money, a recent study shows. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/08/11/542607941/nearly-1-in-5-hospice-patients-discharged-while-still-alive

item.title: 2016 Hit Records For Global Temperature And Climate Extremes
item.description: August 10, 2017 - An annual report, comprising data from scientists across the globe, shows it was the warmest on records that date back 137 years. It also saw the highest sea levels and lowest polar sea ice.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 10, 2017 - An annual report, comprising data from scientists across the globe, shows it was the warmest on records that date back 137 years. It also saw the highest sea levels and lowest polar sea ice. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/08/10/542720189/2016-hit-records-for-global-temperature-and-climate-extremes

item.title: People Back Editing Genes To Treat Disease, But Are Wary Of Inheritable Changes
item.description: August 10, 2017 - Scientists are getting closer to being able to alter people's genes permanently. A survey found that people are more cautious about changes that could be passed on to future generations.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 10, 2017 - Scientists are getting closer to being able to alter people's genes permanently. A survey found that people are more cautious about changes that could be passed on to future generations. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/08/10/542659066/people-back-editing-genes-to-treat-disease-but-are-wary-of-inheritable-changes

item.title: Environmental Penalties Down Under President Trump
item.description:
August 10, 2017 - A new report shows the EPA has collected 60 percent less in civil penalties from polluters compared with recent administrations.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/08/10/542603483/environmental-penalties-are-down-under-president-trump
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 10, 2017 - A new report shows the EPA has collected 60 percent less in civil penalties from polluters compared with recent administrations. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/10/542603483/environmental-penalties-are-down-under-president-trump

item.title: Widowed Early, A Cancer Doctor Writes About The Harm Of Medical Debt
item.description: August 10, 2017 - A decade after the death of her husband, Fumiko Chino is studying the strain that uncovered medical costs put on cancer patients, even those who have insurance.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 10, 2017 - A decade after the death of her husband, Fumiko Chino is studying the strain that uncovered medical costs put on cancer patients, even those who have insurance. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/08/10/542589232/widowed-early-a-cancer-doctor-writes-about-the-harm-of-medical-debt

item.title: As Eclipse Madness Sweeps U.S., A Stonehenge Made Of Cars Prepares
item.description: August 10, 2017 - Carhenge in Alliance, Neb., will be prime viewing for this month's total solar eclipse. The town is preparing for thousands of visitors.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 10, 2017 - Carhenge in Alliance, Neb., will be prime viewing for this month's total solar eclipse. The town is preparing for thousands of visitors. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/08/10/541583064/as-eclipse-madness-sweeps-u-s-a-stonehenge-made-of-cars-prepares

item.title: Hurricane Franklin, First Of Atlantic Season, Barrels Toward Mexico's Coast
item.description: August 9, 2017 - The storm is expected to make landfall north of Veracruz, where it could dump as much as 15 inches of rain, causing "life-threatening flash floods and mudslides."
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 9, 2017 - The storm is expected to make landfall north of Veracruz, where it could dump as much as 15 inches of rain, causing "life-threatening flash floods and mudslides." http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/08/09/542510195/hurricane-franklin-first-of-atlantic-season-barrels-toward-mexicos-coast
